titlestmt.titleproper: Finding Aid for the Medical Artifacts Collection

did.text: Drugs peddled by native medicine men of French Morocco. Three phials containing: a) worm seeds for worm cures, b) iron fillings for the eyes, c) pebbles for the heart.
did.provenance: Donated by Miss Eleanor Fair, Metropolitan Life Insurance Co., New York, 1938.

did.text: Mortar (stone) and pestle (stone with wooden handle). This type of mortar was used in doctors' offices in rural areas throughout the nineteenth century. Used by William P. Moseley and his son in Buckingham County, Virginia, 1818-1896. Dr. Shelley noted: "Probably Italian and several centuries old."

Indian Turnip. Sliced and eaten with salt this was widely used as an aphrodisiac in the U.S. rural South. Early 20th century. These objects represent objects relating to popular medicine, collected by doctors in the rural South. One of them, Dr. Sam Morris of Alabama, was a black physician who collected many amulets and medicines from black southerners.
did.provenance: Donated by Dr. William Groce Harrison.

did.text: Bottle containing hog-hoof (pigs' toe nails). Tea made from this was used to cure pneumonia, bronchitis and flu. U.S. rural South. Early 20th century. These objects represent objects relating to popular medicine, collected by doctors in the rural South. One of them, Dr. Sam Morris of Alabama, was a black physician who collected many amulets and medicines from black southerners.
did.provenance: Donated by Dr. William Groce Harrison.

did.text: Bottle with pellets of sheeps' dung. Tea made from this was used to make measles break out. U.S. rural South. Early 20th century. These objects represent objects relating to popular medicine, collected by doctors in the rural South. One of them, Dr. Sam Morris of Alabama, was a black physician who collected many amulets and medicines from black southerners.
did.provenance: Donated by Dr. William Groce Harrison.

did.text: Yellow-root. A decoction made from this was used for purgation and stomach disorders. When worn in a bag hung from the neck, it was expected to prevent all intestinal diseases. U.S. rural South. Early 20th century. These objects represent objects relating to popular medicine, collected by doctors in the rural South. One of them, Dr. Sam Morris of Alabama, was a black physician who collected many amulets and medicines from black southerners.
did.provenance: Donated by Dr. William Groce Harrison.

did.text: Branches of witch-hazel. Decoctions from which were used as effective abortifacients. Collected by Dr. Sam Morris (black physician), Alabama. U.S. rural South. Early 20th century. These objects represent objects relating to popular medicine, collected by doctors in the rural South. One of them, Dr. Sam Morris of Alabama, was a black physician who collected many amulets and medicines from black southerners.
did.provenance: Donated by Dr. William Groce Harrison.

did.text: Tooth of some animal. Suspended from the neck, it was to insure victory over enemies. U.S. rural South. Early 20th century. These objects represent objects relating to popular medicine, collected by doctors in the rural South. One of them, Dr. Sam Morris of Alabama, was a black physician who collected many amulets and medicines from black southerners.
did.provenance: Donated by Dr. William Groce Harrison.

did.text: "John the Conqueror." A piece of jointed root of an unidentified plant, to be chewed and spat out just before undertaking any severe task. It is believed to insure success in labor, lobe and battle. Collected by Dr. Sam Morris, Alabama. U.S. rural South, Early 20th century. These objects represent objects relating to popular medicine, collected by doctors in the rural South. One of them, Dr. Sam Morris of Alabama, was a black physician who collected many amulets and medicines from black southerners.
did.provenance: Donated by Dr. William Groce Harrison.

did.text: Irish Potatoes (2). A black man nearing 80 used these two Irish potatoes for ten years or more as an effective preventative against rheumatism and lumbago -- one for each disease. They are dry without being brittle, and seem petrified. U.S. rural South. Early 20th century. These objects represent objects relating to popular medicine, collected by doctors in the rural South. One of them, Dr. Sam Morris of Alabama, was a black physician who collected many amulets and medicines from black southerners.
did.provenance: Donated by Dr. William Groce Harrison.

did.text: Sheeps' dung. Tea made from this was used to make measles break out. U.S. rural South. Early 20th century. These objects represent objects relating to popular medicine, collected by doctors in the rural South. One of them, Dr. Sam Morris of Alabama, was a black physician who collected many amulets and medicines from black southerners.
did.provenance: Donated by Dr. William Groce Harrison.

did.text: Coin (U.S. half dollar). Removed from the oesophageal constriction of a black woman who had accidentally swallowed it. She claimed to have used it successfully as an unfailing contraceptive measure, merely by retaining it in the mouth during coition. The coin had been conjured by an old conjuring man. U.S. rural South. Early 20th century. These objects represent objects relating to popular medicine, collected by doctors in the rural South. One of them, Dr. Sam Morris of Alabama, was a black physician who collected many amulets and medicines from black southerners.
did.provenance: Donated by Dr. William Groce Harrison.

did.text: Mole foot. Worn suspended from the neck to prevent venereal diseases. Collected by Dr. Sam Thelford, Boligee, Greene County, Alabama. U.S. rural South. Early 20th century. These objects represent objects relating to popular medicine, collected by doctors in the rural South. One of them, Dr. Sam Morris of Alabama, was a black physician who collected many amulets and medicines from black southerners.
did.provenance: Donated by Dr. William Groce Harrison.

did.text: French silver franc worn by black woman of 75 on a cord around waist for ten years to "prevent being conjured." She believed that without it she would have been dead. U.S. rural South. Early 20th century. These objects represent objects relating to popular medicine, collected by doctors in the rural South. One of them, Dr. Sam Morris of Alabama, was a black physician who collected many amulets and medicines from black southerners.
did.provenance: Donated by Dr. William Groce Harrison.

did.text: Half-dime (U.S.). Worn about the ankle by a black woman for twelve years to attract and retain lovers. Collected by B. B. Sims, Talladega, Alabama. U. S. rural South. Early 20th century. These objects represent objects relating to popular medicine, collected by doctors in the rural South. One of them, Dr. Sam Morris of Alabama, was a black physician who collected many amulets and medicines from black southerners.
did.provenance: Donated by Dr. William Groce Harrison.

did.text: Obstetrical forceps, ca. 1870.
Pill tile. Used in the practice of medicine in the U.S. 19th century.
did.provenance: Donated by Dr. P. E. Tucker, Buckingham County, Virginia.

did.text: Prescription scale. Portable scale marketed under the name of Dr. C. F. Fitch. Patented September 29, 1885. Small rectangular chrome-plated metal box with a balancing slide rule attached to a spoon. Previous card stated: "Measuring weighing machine. Used in the practice of medicine in the U.S. during the period 1800-1896. Used by Dr. William P. Moseley of Buckingham Co., Virginia. (He had three sons in the Confederate Army: Col. W. P., Col. Edgar, and Captain Samuel P. Moseley)." Note: Stored with object #39
did.provenance: Donated by Mrs. Moseley Smith, through the courtesy of Dr. William Groce Harrison.

did.text: Two single-bladed scarificators or spring lancets. Used for blood-letting in the practice of medicine until the end of the 19th century. Used by Dr. William P. Moseley of Buckingham County, Virginia. Note: the blade is broken on one of the scarificators.
did.provenance: Donated by Mrs. Moseley Smith, through the courtesy of Dr. William Groce Harrison.

did.text: Nitze Cystoscope. Ca. 1930.
did.provenance: Donated by Dr. Harry Shelley.

did.text: Two drug boxes U.S. 19th and early 20th century. Round.
Buzzard quills and copper amulet used to make teething easy. Collected by Dr. W. H. Harper, Selma, Alabama. U.S. rural South. Early 20th century.
did.provenance: Donated by Dr. William Groce Harrison.

did.text: Copper amulet used to make teething easy. Collected by Dr. W. H. Harper, Selma, Alabama. U.S. rural South. Early 20th century.
did.provenance: Donated by Dr. William Groce Harrison.

did.text: Rabbit tobacco -- worn as a charm to prevent asthma. A decoction made from this plant was used for the treatment of asthma. U.S. rural South. Early 20th century.
did.provenance: Donated by Dr. William Groce Harrison.

did.text: Mole feet. A charm worn to ease teething. Copper pennies were supposed to neutralize baby scents. Collected by Dr. W. H. Harper, Selma, Alabama. U.S. rural South. Early 20th century.
did.provenance: Donated by Dr. William Groce Harrison.

did.text: May apple root, the tea of which is used for all forms of "stomach trouble.” Collected and donated by Dr. William Groce Harrison, Birmingham, Alabama. U.S. rural South. Early 20th century.
did.provenance: Donated by Dr. William Groce Harrison.

did.text: Copper wire worn on the wrist to prevent all sickness and insure physical strength. Collected by Dr. Sam Thelford, Boligee, Greene County, Alabama. U.S. rural South. Early 20th century.
did.provenance: Donated by Dr. William Groce Harrison.

did.text: Buckeyes, worn on cord about the waist to prevent heart disease and to win the love of young women. Also used to prevent hemorrhoids. Collected and donated by Dr. William Groce Harrison, Birmingham, Alabama. U.S. rural South. Early 20th century.
did.provenance: Donated by Dr. William Groce Harrison.

did.text: Copper penny and some unidentified bits of wood. A charm to make teething easy. Collected by Dr. W. H. Harper, Selma, Alabama. U.S. rural South. Early 20th century.
did.provenance: Donated by Dr. William Groce Harrison.

did.text: Copper pennies (two). These coins were worn around the neck by a black woman, age 45, as a neuralgic prophylaxis. They were reputed to have cured an attack; however, in the meantime some bad teeth had been removed. Collected by H. S. Castleman, Sylacauga, Alabama. U.S. rural south. Early 20th century.
did.provenance: Donated by Dr. William Groce Harrison.

did.text: Cloth-covered string. String worn by white male, age 34, who had used it at the suggestion of an acquaintance, who claimed that such a string saturated with turpentine and tied around the waist would cure chills and fever. When the string was removed the man's rectal temperature was 106.3 which was three or four hours after the malarial paroxysm. Members of this man's family were infected with malaria, and he was not well and had been advised to take treatment, which he ignored. He admitted that he had been tortured the night before by the turpentine saturated string. Proper treatment for malaria promptly controlled the situation. U.S. rural South. Early 20th century.
did.provenance: Donated by Dr. William Groce Harrison.

did.text: Amulet of small cotton bag and two beads of unidentified substance. Said "to keep the blues away." Collected by Dr. W. H. Harper, Selma, Alabama. U.S. rural South. Early 20th century.
did.provenance: Donated by Dr. William Groce Harrison.

did.text: Plaster cast of the hand of Dr. Barney Brooks. Original plaster-cast of the hand of Dr. Barney Brooks, prepared by the son of Dr. Mims at the request of Dr. Allen Whipple for his "Collection of Model Hands of Famous Surgeons" in Columbia University.
did.provenance: Donated by Dr. Barney Brooks, December 3, 1951.

did.text: Saddle-bag scales (for weighing medicines). Wooden box with brass post and slide out drawer for scales. Early to mid-nineteenth century. Donated by Mrs. Florence Pratt of Buckingham Court House, Virginia. Note: Objects #122 and #39 are stored with it.
Box containing a surgeon's instruments. Two saws, three knives, two other instruments, and two needles. It contains space for three additional instruments which are missing.

Saddle-bags made of leather, with leather loops inside to hold medicine bottles. Contains five bottles, some with powders, Some with dried liquids. Used by Dr. William P. Moseley of Buckingham County, Virginia, for fifty years. U.S. Nineteenth century. Her husband used these saddlebags as well as the instruments listed in this inventory in practice. He Was born May 31, 1794 and died April 2, 1863. He attended the University of Virginia from 1816-17, and graduated in medicine from the University of Pennsylvania. He lived and practiced in Buckingham Co., Virginia. His three sons: Col. William P.; Lieut. Col. Edgar F.; and Capt. Samuel P. fought in the Confederate army.
did.provenance: Donated by Mrs. William Moseley Smith.

did.text: Pocket case of old surgical instruments used by Dr. John A. Tillow, Hendersonville, Tennessee about 1870. Donated by his grandson Mr. Bransford Stone, November 10, 1942.
did.provenance: Donated by Bransford Stone.

did.text: Scarificator. Belonged to Dr. William P. Moseley, Buckingham County, Virginia.
did.provenance: Donated by Mrs. William Moseley Smith.

did.text: Instrument case of Dr. William P. Moseley of Buckingham County, Virginia. Case is of red leather and contains eight instruments; six instruments are apparently missing.
did.provenance: Donated by Mrs. William Moseley Smith.

did.text: Wooden box containing two medicine scales and six weights. Used by Dr. Arthur Moseley of Buckingham Co., Virginia.
did.provenance: Donated by Mrs. William Moseley Smith.

did.text: Chinese ivory figurine from the interior of China, obtained by Miss Mary Cutter from a Chinese physician. It was used for women patients in this manner: Modesty on part of the patient and custom forbade a personal examination; so the patient indicated on the ivory figurine the location of the pain, and the physician then prescribed. Such figurines were formerly in general use in China and still are in certain sections. Figurine is quite old (ca. 1800) and very rare.
did.provenance: Donated by Dr. Cobb Pilcher.

did.text: Wooden case lined with velvet, containing operating set (seven instruments) belonging to Dr. W. M. Cunningham. Dating from 1890, it was used by him in a double amputation of a patient's legs below the knee in a waiting room of a railroad station, using a caboose cushion on the floor for an operating table. The patient, Rufe Bivens, lived many years thereafter as a useful citizen.

Sinhalese Ola (palm-leaf manuscript). Written on the prepared leaves of the Palmyra Palm (Borasus flabellifer) about 1745 A.D. The text is translated chiefly from the original Sanskrit writings of Charka into a mixture of Sinhalese prose and verse, dealing with various medical subjects. A part of the work is missing. Wooden covers are lacquered, and, like the binding cord and medallion (broken and in separate box) are also modern, but made by Kandyan workmen after antique models.
did.provenance: Donated by Dr. Casey Wood, Chicago, January 8, 1927.

did.text: Box containing three lancets. Two used by Dr. Mathieu Derivaux. The third, a cupping lancet, was used by Dr. J. O. Kirkpatrick, Nashville. All three lancets are folded between two leaves of tortoise shell.

Civil War Era Surgical Instruments. Two instruments (folded between tortoise shell leaves) from a pocket case of instruments purchased in 1859 and used through the Civil War and afterward by Dr. J. T. Harrison, Talladega, Alabama. He graduated from the University of Nashville in 1855.

Portraits of Vanderbilt Chancellor Carmichael and Dean Leathers Wooden box, 11" x 14," containing two portraits of Vanderbilt Chancellor Carmichael and Dean Leathers presented to Lt. Col. George W. Reyer, Commanding Officer of the 300th General Hospital.

Truax surgical pump 1890, made by Truax Greene & Co., Chicago Ill. Used for aspirating or irrigating cavities: "Stiff rubber tubing is inserted, then turn the crank forwards or backwards for the results desired."

Wooden case, velvet lined, with ten surgical instruments (one or possibly more missing). Instruments were given as the prize in surgery by Dr. Briggs, the professor to Robert Lee Vaught of Mason County, West Virginia, at his graduation on February 25, 1886. Dr. Vaught settled in Chattanooga as a general practitioner, specializing in surgery. Soon after he settled, he was elected Professor of Anatomy in the Chattanooga Medical College, a position he held until his death on August 28 1895 when he drowned in the Great Kanawha River while enroute to visit his mother. He was born May 24, 1863.
Bronze medallion of the Johns Hopkins Hospital, to commemorate fifty years of service to humanity, science, and education 1889-1939.
Bronze medallion of William Beaumont 1785-1853, XIII International Physiological Congress, Boston, 1929.
Bronze medallion of Stephen Smith, founder of the American Public Health Association, commissioned to commemorate the semicentennial meeting of the association in 1922.
Bronze medallion of Frank Billings, Dean of the Faculty, Rush Medical College, 1924.
Bronze medal with pin and ribbon from the Tennessee State Medical Association 1930 annual convention in Nashville and commissioned to commemorate their centennial celebration.
Wooden box, velvet lined, containing enema from the Truss Works, Sheffield, England.
Ear speculum "before the days of light."
did.provenance: Donated by Dr. J. B. Hibbitts, Jr.

did.text: Korean medical instruments. Bone tube with meander- patterned metal cap, containing one large knife - "Chine," and three needle-like small "chines.” The large chine is used to open abscesses. The small chines are stuck into certain parts of the flesh for various purposes. Contained in blue cardboard box.

Korean herb doctor's drugs. Note: The drugs described on the following cards are used by Korean herb doctors. Besides regular medical doctors, there are two types of herb doctors in Korea. The older type, which still flourishes in rural areas, is learned through an apprenticeship. The modern type, which is licensed by the government, requires a student, who has attained the equivalent of a high school education, to study pharmacology in an institution. Largely, herbal medicine is taught there, but western pharmacology is taught also. It appears that the herbal medicines in this collection derive from the old-type of herb doctor. These Korean herbal medicines come in their original paper bags, and are imprinted with their names in Chinese characters. The herb medicines were introduced from China and retain their Chinese names. The small paper envelopes, imprinted with Korean characters, were merely used as containers for the want of others: they derive from the Graham Tuberculosis Sanatorium (Korean name: Kwang Ju Chai Joong). The drugs are not from the hospital.

Bryan, Worcester Allen Diploma for the Doctor of Medicine degree from Vanderbilt University awarded to Worcester Allen Bryan, April 1, 1899. Parchment, written in Latin, and encased between two plates of glass. Added to inventory August 25, 1995

Bryan, Worcester Allen. Diploma for the Master of Arts Degree from Cumberland University awarded to Worcester Allen Bryan, 1897. Parchment, written in Latin, and encased between two plates of glass (glass broken). Added to inventory August 25, 1995

Bryan, Worcester Allen. Diploma for the Bachelor of Arts Degree from Cumberland University awarded to Worcester Allen Bryan, 1894. Parchment, written in Latin, and encased between two plates of glass. Added to inventory August 25, 1995
Patterson, John W. Matted photograph of Dean John W. Patterson., ca. 1965. Added to inventory August 25, 1995

Orthopedics Framed composite of well-known orthopedic surgeons including: William John Little (1810-1894), Buckminster Brown (1819-1891), Hugh Owens Thomas (1834-1891), E. H. Bradford (1848-1926), John Ridlon (1852-1936). Added to inventory August 25, 1995. Transferred by Vanderbilt Department of Orthopedics.

University of Illinois College of Medicine. Roll containing twelve hand-drawn pencil sketches of prominent men in medicine including: Andreas Vesalius and Leonardo DaVinci. One of the drawings has University of Illinois College of Medicine written on the back. Also, they appear to be cartoons that were used to transfer the images onto another medium. Added to inventory August 25, 1995.

Shelley, Harry Sandberg. Roll containing certificates and diplomas awarded to Dr. Harry S. Shelley. Including: M.D. degree, University of Maryland, 1931; B.S. degree, Drexel Institute, 1924; Free Masons of Maryland, 1956; Medical license, State of Tennessee, 1947; and three from University Hospital, Baltimore, 1932-1934. Added to inventory August 25, 1995.

Jacoby, Kurt. Reproduction of a certificate given to Kurt Jacoby from Academic Press on occasion of his 75th birthday. Sent from James Barsky, President of Academic Press to Dr. Sidney P. Colowick, Vanderbilt. Added to inventory August 25, 1995.

American Institute of Nutrition Group photograph of American Institute of Nutrition meeting, Cornell University Medical College, March 28, 1934. Attached sheet identifies many in the photograph. Added to inventory August 25, 1995.

Harvey, William. Print of an Engraving of William Harvey (1578-1657) demonstrating his experiments on deer to King Charles I and the boy prince. Engraving by Harvey Lemon after the painting by Robert Hannah in the Royal College of Physicians. Limited edition print from Jeremy Norman. Number 12 of 300, 1984. Added to inventory August 25, 1995.

Bernard, Claude. Print of a lithograph of Claude Bernard performing an experiment. By Eugène Louis Pirodon after the painting by Lon Lhermitte in the Sorbonne. Limited edition print for Jeremy Norman. Number 13 of 300, 1984. Added to inventory August 28, 1995.
Sebrell, William Henry. Large oversize photograph mounted on a rigid foam board of William Henry Sebrell. Added to Collection August 29, 1995.
Flexner, Simon. A framed color photograph of a portrait of Simon Flexner (apparently located at the University of Pennsylvania School of Medicine).
did.provenance: Donated by Dr. John Flexner, August 29, 1995.

did.text: Flexner, Simon. A framed and autographed photograph of Simon Flexner.
did.provenance: Donated by Dr. John Flexner, August 29, 1995.

did.text: Flexner, Abraham. A framed photograph of Abraham Flexner inscribed to Morris and Marion Flexner (John Flexner’s parents). Removed from frame and placed in Flexner Family Collction.
did.provenance: Donated by Dr. John Flexner, August 29, 1995.

did.text: Flexner, Jacob Aaron. A framed photograph of Dr. Jacob Aaron Flexner, John Flexner’s grandfather, at his desk. Dr. Jacob Flexner received his M.D. degree from the University of Louisville and practiced in Louisville.
did.provenance: Donated by Dr. John Flexner, August 29, 1995.

did.text: Flexner, Morris. A framed photograph of Morris Flexner with an inscription on the back from his wife Marion Flexner to John and Barbara Flexner.
did.provenance: Donated by Dr. John Flexner, August 29, 1995.

did.text: Flexner, Morris. A framed group photograph of the Johns Hopkins class of 1914. Several people in this picture are of interest to Vanderbilt including Edwards Park, father of Charles Rollo Park, seated in the front row third from the right; Max Broedel, seated in the front row, sixth from the right; and Morris Flexner, in the center of the third row.
did.provenance: Donated by Dr. John Flexner, August 29, 1995.

did.text: Goodpasture, Ernest William. Desk chair of Dr. Ernest W. Goodpasture, Professor of Pathology, Vanderbilt University, 1925-1955. The swivel office chair with wheels is made of mahogany and the seat and back area are covered with black vinyl. Transferred by Vanderbilt Department of Pathology, May 4, 1995 through the agency of Dr. Robert Collins.

Goldberger-Sebrell Chair. Office chair used by Dr. Joseph Goldberger, and Dr William H. Sebrell. The swivel chair with wheels is made of oak with a brown vinyl seat. Two plates are attached. The first reading: “The Goldberger Chair presented with appreciation to William H. Sebrell Jr. July 31, 1955;” and the second reading: “Used by Goldberger 1920-1928, Used by Sebrell, 1929-1984. Presented to Vanderbilt University December 31, 1984."

Vanderbilt University School of Medicine. Ben Witt Key Annual Award established in 1938 by Dr. Ben Witt Key, an alumnus, and presented to the fourth year student who was among the five highest in scholarship and judged by the faculty to be outstanding in scientific ability, character and personality. Presented to William Wesley Frye, 1939; Edmund Woodward Benz, 1940; and James Hubert Baxter, Jr., 1941. The cup is sterling silver and 12.5 inches in height.
Flexner, Simon. William Wood Gerhard Medal awarded to Simon Flexner from the Philadelphia Pathological Society on January 8, 1931.
did.provenance: Donated by Dr. John Flexner, November 7, 1995.

did.text: Flexner, Morris. Framed autographed photograph of Lewellys F. Barker, inscribed to Dr. Morris Flexner.

did.text: Physick, Philip Syng. Framed print of Philip Syng Physick, M.D. (1768-1837) by Henry Innman, No. 5 in the Great American Surgeons Series, Ethicon Suture Laboratories, ca 1960. Added to inventory November 7, 1995.

Deaver, John Blair. Framed print of John Blair Deaver, M.D. 1855-1931. From the portrait by Adolph Borie. No. 1 in the Great American Surgeons Series, Ethicon Suture Laboratories, ca 1960. Added to inventory November 7, 1995.

Shippen, Jr., William. Framed print of William Shippen Jr., M.D. 1736-1808. From the portrait by Gilbert Stuart. No. 6 in the Great American Surgeons Series, Ethicon Suture Laboratories, ca 1960. Added to the inventory November 8, 1995.

Microscope Compound monocular microscope manufactured by the Spencer Company, Buffalo New York, ca. 1925. Black with mirror, condenser, square stage, fine and coarse adjustment, mechanical slide attachment manufactured by Bausch and Lomb. A brass plate inscribed “VUMSH” is attached to the horseshoe base. Added to inventory November 8, 1995.
Vanderbilt University Medical Center. Plaque, bronze. Mildred B. Ansley Cardiac Catheterization Laboratory September 1980. Added to inventory November 9, 1995.
Eye Chart. Scherings Children’s Eye Chart. Letters on one side and figures on the reverse Ca. 1960. Added to inventory November 9, 1995.
Eye Chart. American Optical Kindergarten Eye Test Chart. Ca. 1950 Added to inventory November 9, 1995.

Eye Chart. Snellen’s Test Types. Published by E. B. Meyrowitz Surgical Instruments Co. Ca. 1940s. Added to inventory November 9, 1995.
Eye Chart. American Optical Visual Acuity Chart for Amblyopic Adults and Children. Conrad Berens, M.D. Ca. 1960. Added to inventory November 9, 1995.
Eye Chart. Eye chart containing numbers. Ca. 1940s Added to inventory November 9, 1995.
Eye Chart. Lancaster-Reagan Astigmatic Dial. Published by George Tieman & Company, Long Island, New York. Added to inventory November 9, 1995.

Vanderbilt University School of Medicine. Print of a pen and ink drawing of the entrance of Vanderbilt University School of Medicine by Warren L. Kirbo, November 1985. Signed and numbered (36/260) print. Added to inventory November 9, 1995.

Vanderbilt University School of Nursing. Nursing History Society. Nursing Dolls dressed in costumes of nurses throughout history including: Priestess, 400 B.C.; Augustinian Sister, 500 A.D.; Beguine, 1200 A.D.; Hospitaliere de Ste. Marie 1300-1400; Sairey Gamp 1800-1900; Sister of Charity 1800-1900 (damaged); Florence Nightingale; Public Health Nurse, 20th Century (damaged); and nursing students at Vanderbilt 1927-1950. There is also contained in the box 4 stands to support the dolls, and a nursing cap. Note: The dolls are not numbered.
did.provenance: Donated by A. Harris, VUSN, September 8, 1994.

did.text: Vanderbilt University School of Nursing. Nursing History Society. Plaque, Nurse of the Year 1974 awarded to Ruth Spurrier. Presented to the Nursing History Society by Elizabeth Spurrier Holmes, sister of the recipient, December 3, 1987. Added to inventory November 9, 1995.
Vanderbilt University School of Nursing. Nursing History Society. Alcohol burner ca. 1930. Used at Vanderbilt Hospital. Glass with metal screw-type wick holder. Added to inventory November 9, 1995.
Vanderbilt University School of Nursing. Nursing History Society. Glass mortar form old Vanderbilt University Hospital Medication Room D7200. Added to inventory November 9, 1995.
Vanderbilt University School of Nursing. Nursing History Society. Door knobs from old Hospital. One is glass with a brass ring, and the other is brushed steel. Added to inventory November 9, 1995.
Vanderbilt University School of Nursing. Nursing History Society. Inkwell and 3 pen holders form Nurse’s Station D7200 Wing. Ca. 1940. Added to inventory November 9, 1995.

Vanderbilt University School of Nursing. Nursing History Society. Four glass syringes and four needles. Ca. 1940, Eisele & Company, Nashville and 1 form Becton Dickinson & Company. Contained in a plastic bag. Added to inventory November 9, 1995.

Vanderbilt University School of Nursing. Nursing History Society. China from Vanderbilt Hospital. Two Pyrex cups, Four light-brown small cups and a creamer, and one saucer. Added to inventory November 9, 1995.
Vanderbilt University School of Nursing. Nursing History Society. Stainless steel pitcher with “4500 CLASSROOM” etched on the side. Added to inventory November 9, 1995.

Nashville Academy of Medicine. Composite photograph of the Nashville Academy of Medicine and Davidson County Medical Society members 1937-38. Rolled and contained in a cardboard tube. Added to inventory November 22, 1995.

Bernard, Claude. Print of a lithograph of Claude Bernard performing an experiment. By Eugène Louis Pirodon after the painting by Leon Lhermitte in the Sorbonne. Limited edition print for Jeremy Norman. Number 17 of 300, 1984. Added to inventory November 22, 1995.

Meacham Completed preparatory courses in German, English, History, Algebra, and Geometry. Dated June 3, 1903. Rolled and brittle, contained in a cardboard tube. Added to inventory November 22, 1995.

Meacham, Martin Alexander. Diploma for degree of Doctor of Medicine from Vanderbilt University awarded to Martin Alexander Meacham May 1, 1907. Printed in Latin on parchment. Rolled and contained in a cardboard tube. Added to inventory November 22, 1995.

Anatomical Charts. American Froshe Anatomical Charts. Edited, revised and augmented by Max Brodel. Copyright 1918 by A. J. Nystrom & Co Publishers, Chicago. Four Plates: (1) Human Skeleton; (2) Human Muscles; (3) Circulatory System, Nervous System; and (4) Male and Female Genito-Urinary System (actually labeled “Plate 10"). Added to inventory November 22, 1995.

Doctor’s Bag. Black vinyl doctor’s bag, plastic handles, expansion lock strap missing. Ca. 1940s. Note: Items 1190-1208 all belonged to Dr Kennon who practiced as an ear nose and throat specialist in Nashville from the 1940s to the early 1980s. All are contained in the doctor’s bag.

did.text: Ear Instruments. Five stainless steel elevators and retractors manufactured by Klenk. There is a note attached by Dr. Kennon explaining that the instruments were purchased in 1953 from a New York company and were designed by Dr. Sam Rosen for stapes mobilization surgery. The first stapes mobilization surgery in Middle Tennessee was performed with these instruments.

did.text: Zulliger, Hans. The Behn-Rorschach-Test. Bern, Switzerland: Verlag Hans Huber, Grune & Stratton Inc., Distributors for the U.S.A. (copyright 1941)1956. Ten psycho-diagnostic plates and a text book.

did.text: Harrower, M. R. Psychodiagnostic Inkblots: (A Parallel Series to Rorschach Blots). Josiah Macy Foundation: 1941. Ten diagnostic plates and manual.

did.text: Symonds Picture-Story Test. Symonds Picture-Story Test. New York: Bureau of Publications, Teachers College, Columbia University, 1948. Twenty psycho-diagnostic plates.

did.text: Bellak, Leopold, and Bellak, Sonya Sorel. Children’s Appreciation Test (C.A.T.). Seventh printing, third and revised edition. New York: C.P.S. Co., 1959. Ten psycho-diagnostic plates.

did.text: Bellak, Leopold, and Bellak, Sonya Sorel. Senior Appreciation Technique (S.A.T.). Larchmont, New York: C.P.S. Inc., 1973. Sixteen diagnostic plates and manual.

did.text: Blum, Gerald. The Blacky Pictures. New York: The Psychological Corporation, 1950. Twelve psycho-diagnostic plates.

did.text: The Michigan Picture Test. The Michigan Picture Test. Chicago: Science Research Associates, Inc., 1953. Sixteen psycho-diagnostic plates.
did.provenance: Donated by Dr. Warren Webb, January 24, 1997.

did.text: Sines, J.O., and Parker, J. D. Missouri Children’s Picture Series. 1964. Approximately 240 cards.
did.provenance: Donated by Dr. Warren Webb, January 24, 1997.

did.text: Psycho-Diagnostic Puzzles Two picture puzzles of prints of paintings by Jessie Wilcox Smith entitled: “Playing Mother” and “Off to Play Stutsman”. Printed by Sterling Company, Chicago.
did.provenance: Donated by Dr. Warren Webb, January 24, 1997.

did.text: Pictorial Completion Test Illustrated by Marguerite Davis. Published and manufactured by Stoelting Company Chicago, Illinois. Copyright, 1918. Contained in a square wooden case, the test consists of a series of 11 color illustrations mounted on two plywood boards, representing a sequence of situations or events occurring during a day in the life of a boy. Each illustration contains a one inch square cutout. Each picture is to be completed by a selection of one of the 60 accompanying squares that would best complete the illustration.
did.provenance: Donated by Dr. Warren Webb, January 24, 1997.

did.text: Pictorial Completion Test -- II By William Healey Illustrated by Marguerite Davis. Published and manufactured by Stoelting Company Chicago, Illinois. 1964.A reproduction of the above, and contained in a square cardboard box, the test consists of a series of 11 color illustrations mounted on two plywood boards, representing a sequence of situations or events occurring during a day in the life of a boy. Each illustration contains a one-inch square cutout. Each picture is to be completed by a selection of one of the 60 accompanying squares that would best complete the illustration.
did.provenance: Donated by Dr. Warren Webb, January 24, 1997.

did.text: Pictorial Completion Test Illustrated by E. Manierre. Published and manufactured by Stoelting Company Chicago, Illinois, ca. 1930. Contained in a wooden case, the test consists of a large illustration mounted on a plywood board. The illustration depicts ten scenes in which various activities are being depicted. There are ten one square inch cut outs adjacent to each scene Each scene is to be completed by a selection of one of the 50 accompanying squares that would best complete the illustration.
did.provenance: Donated by Dr. Warren Webb, January 24, 1997.

did.text: Psycho-Diagnostic Puzzles Two wood block puzzles manufactured by the Stoelting Company Chicago, Illinois. Both are uncolored and unfinished plywood boards that have cut out shapes. One has exclusively rectangles, triangles and a square, while the other has circular pieces.
did.provenance: Donated by Dr. Warren Webb, January 24, 1997.

did.text: Bellvue Intelligence Test Manufactured by the Psychological Corporation, New York. ca 1940s Consists of six parts contained in separate boxes. Three are wood puzzles of a human face profile, a human hand, and a mannequin. Two are picture cards, and one is a box of sixteen one cubic inch colored blocks arranged to make designs (known as the Kohs Block Design Test) There are also nine cards illustrating test patterns contained in this box of blocks.
did.provenance: Donated by Dr. Warren Webb, January 24, 1997

did.text: Kohs Block Design Test. Manufactured by the C. H. Stoelting Company Chicago, Illinois. Sixteen one cubic inch colored blocks with 18 cards illustrating test patterns. Also, a reprint of an article by S. C. Kohs entitled “The Block Design Tests undated and source not listed. Ca. 1920s
did.provenance: Donated by Dr. Warren Webb, January 24, 1997

did.text: The Minnesota Multiphasic Personality Inventory, Minneapolis: University of Minnesota Press, 1942. Contained in a box, the test consists of approximately 350 cards containing statments in which the person being analyzed is supposed to classify as being “true,” “false,” or “cannot say.” Note that the following items belonged to Virginia Kirk. See biographical file for more information about her.
did.provenance: Donated by Dr. Warren Webb, January 24, 1997

did.text: Pseudo-Isochromatic Plates for Testing Color Perception. American Optical Company, Beck Engraving Company, 1940. Test used to determine color blindness. Note that the following items belonged to Virginia Kirk. See biographical file for more information about her.
did.provenance: Donated by Dr. Warren Webb, January 24, 1997.

did.text: Bell Jar. Large glass bell jar intended for use as a dust cover for a microscope. Glass dome with black lacquered wooden pedestal. This particular jar was used in the student laboratories of Vanderbilt School of Medicine and Hospital when it relocated from downtown Nashville to the Vanderbilt campus in 1925. Inventoried October 10, 2018.

did.text: Student Microscope. Miniature drum compound monocular microscope, brass manufactured by Noel P. Lerebours. Paris circa 1846-50. Contained in mahogany wood case with two additional lenses and a pair of brass tweezers. Belonged to donor’s uncle Dr. Robert Weill who was Professor of Dental Surgery and later Director of the School of Dental Surgery in Paris. Inventoried October 22, 2018.
did.provenance: Donated by Dr. Ralph Lampert (VU 1961), March 2012.

did.text: Amputation Surgical Kit. Civil War era amputation kit manufactured by Wiegand & Snowden Philadelphia. Circa 1840 -1850. Contained in wooden case lined in purple velvet (faded to grey) Incomplete. Includes two saws, two knives, a tenaculum probe, and a tourniquet. Reportedly used by a Confederate surgeon during the Civil War. Inventoried October 22, 2018. Donated through the agency of Dr. Robert Collins.

Korean drug. Native name: "Taik Sa." A root eaten as food by the Japanese, it has a diuretic effect and is used for that purpose by the Korean medicine men.
Korean drug. Native name: "Yong Sa Mal.” Mercuric oxide used as a medicine for ulcers in various ways.
Korean drug. Native name: "Paik Chul." A root used for diarrheas, vomiting, etc. Has somewhat the effect of opium. It is a gastric tonic, increasing the appetite.
Korean drug. Mercuric oxide ointment used as a medicine for ulcers.
Korean drug. Native name: "O Juk San," (San means powder). Shredded wood, bark and twigs of unidentified plant. Decoction is used for acute abdominal colics.

Korean drug. Native name: "Chun Nam Sung." Root of a flowering plant of this name. Very poisonous. Seems to be used somewhat the way potassium iodide is used in the west. It is used, among other things, to combat glandular enlargement.

Korean drug. Native name: "Pujah" or "Tae Bu Ja.” Dried fruit of a tree. Has an intoxicating effect. Makes the whole body feel hot and heedless of cold weather. Temporarily it greatly increases a person's strength. It is poisonous in larger doses.
Korean drug. Native name: "Pal Mi Tang.” Shredded wood and other unidentified substances, decoction from which is used as an appetizer.
Korean drug. Native name: "Pan Ha." It is the seed of a grass. It has the effect of codeine, to some extent and is especially used to allay coughing.

Korean drug. Native name: "Woo Hwang Po Yong." Pills used for convulsions, green stools, fever, and vomiting in children. Instructions for usage: Grind into fine powder, dissolve in warm water or milk. Dosages to be taken three times a day. For children under 2 years: one pill; 2-3 years: two pills; and 3-5 years: three pills.
Korean drug. Red pills used for indigestion and acute gastritis.

Korean drug. Native name: "Chun Moon Tong." Root probably used as a tonic, it is said to increase strength and agility. It is helpful in lung diseases and weaknesses. Helps to check pulmonary or gastric hemorrhages.

Korean drug. Native name: "Suk Ke Whang." It is a black licorice-like substance. It is supposed to cause the hair tho become white when taken, followed by eating turnips. Often used by would-be office holders to whiten their hair in order to appear older and more dignified. Improves the blood and gives a firm texture to the flesh. Is used also for amenorrhea and do improve dimmed vision. When eaten alone it makes the eye lashes black.
Korean drug. Native name: "Sip Yon Tae Po Tang.” Supposed to be a great tonic for women.
Wilson, Owen. Gum lancet for babies' gums. Ca. 1870.
did.provenance: Donated by Dr. Owen Wilson.

did.text: Civil War. Three amputating knives. Ca. 1850. Possibly used in the Civil War.

Medicine case of Dr. Arthur Moseley of Buckingham County, Virginia. Medicines include: 1. Compound cathartic pills, 2. Wine of Colchicum root, 3. Dover's powder, 4. Fluid extract of Valerian, 5. Tarter emetic. 6. Sulfate of morphia, 7. Ipecacuanha, 8. Antimonial wine, 9. Acetate of lead, 10. Wine of Ipecacuanha, 11. Cannabis sativa, 12. Tincture of aconite, 13. Rhubarb, 14. Extract of Hyoscyami, 15. Alum, 16. Laudanum. Case also contains an instrument for venesection with spare blades, in red morocco leather.
Civil War. Assorted surgical instruments that were possibly used in the Civil War.
did.provenance: Donated by Dr. William Groce Harrison.

did.text: Kinlock's Urethrotome manufactured by the George Tiemann Company.

Wilson, Owen. Cupping set complete with cupping machine, suction pump, and five glass cups. It was given by Dr. Owen Wilson to Dr. Barney Brooks, who gave it to the Library for its contemplated museum. One cup still has the original valve. Contained in a wooden box.
did.provenance: Donated by Dr. Barney Brooks.

did.text: Intubation instruments, one complete set in black leather case lined with red velvet. These instruments were introduced in America by Dr. Joseph O'Dwyer of New York who perfected the method of intubation, and marketed the instruments. A signed a card (February 26, 1894) certifying his personal inspection, is also contained in the case.
did.provenance: Donated by Dr. T. Crowder Chapman, an alumnus.

did.text: Douglas, Richard (“Dixie”). Death mask of Dr. Douglas who was a Professor of gynecology and Abdominal Surgery at Vanderbilt University. When the library of the School of Medicine was founded in 1906, the Nashville Academy of Medicine gave the school a Donated by the private library of Dr. Douglas, which consisted of 2,500 volumes.
did.provenance: Donated by Mrs. George Hale.

did.text: Two Saddlebags of Dr. W. E. Pratt, Buckingham, Virginia, ca. 1895. List of medicines which can still be deciphered from the labels on the glass phials: Creosote, Borax, Morphine sulphate hypodermic, bicarbonate of soda, pulv. opium, nitroglycerin, cordia, camphor, Febralgene - neuralgic acute rheumatism and fevers generally, pepsin, quinea, paregoric gentian, nux vomica, citrate of potassium, potassium arsenate, potassium iodide, bromide potash, potassium bicarbonate, ergot (fluid extract), veratrum, aconite, cinnamon, tincture of meth., salicylic acid zinc sulphate, tincture of digitalis, chloroform, peptenzym tablets, Dad's quinine pills, chocolate coated pills for rhinitis, laxoid tablets containing cascarin, hydrastinine, and other substances.
did.provenance: Donated by Mrs. Florence Pratt, Buckingham, Va.

did.text: Eve, Paul F. Surgical instruments used by Dr. Paul Eve. Presented by Dr. Duncan Eve, Jr. instruments include: three tourniquets, a trephine, a trepanning brace, hand drill, a gynecological Hunter's speculum, and a round wooden plate with a metal attachment on the side and "P. F. Eve" scratched on the top. All ca. 1840-1870. Contained in a green painted wooden box. Note: that only the box is labeled. March 11, 1995.
Three amputation saws. Two are bow saws and one is what is known as a capital saw. All are ca. nineteenth century.
Surgical probes.

Eve, Duncan. Calculi removed by Dr. Duncan Eve, February 16, 1880. Dr. Eve together with Dr. W. F. Glenn on Nashville organized the Nashville Medical College. Dr. Eve was dean of the faculty from the beginning until 1883. (See Philip M. Hamer. The Centennial History of the Tennessee State Medical Association, 1930, pp. 383-4)
Two pair of Smellie's scissors.
Pump for aspirating fluids.
Leather case with 14 surgical clamps, manufactured by George Tiemann, New York.
Trocar, rectal, ca. 1870.

Eve, Paul F. Surgical instruments in black lacquered case lined with red silk. manufactured by Charière, Paris. Eye instruments. Some are missing. One of the instruments has "EVE" etched on the handle. Perhaps instruments belonging to Dr. Paul F. Eve. Ca. 1850.
Venesection instrument of Dr. T. Chalmers Dow. The object described appears to be a single-bladed spring-loaded lancet or scarificator.
Electrical instruments contained in wooden case.
Perkins tractors after Haygarth. Wooden handled, metal with hooked end.

Stethoscope, binaural. George P. Cammann designed the binaural stethoscope in 1851. It did not become known until 1855, when an editorial in the New York Medical Times gave it publicity. Cammann himself used it only on special occasions, for he was afraid habitual use might cause his ears to lose their natural sensitivity.
did.provenance: Donated by Dr Bernard M. Weinstein, Nashville, March 10, 1965.

did.text: Nested weights (similar to Nuremberg weights), 17th century, structured so that the largest cup equals the sum of the weight of the others. The second cup is half the weight of the largest cup. The ratio continues from cup to cup.

Johnson's Uvula scissors.
Three dental forceps.

Wyeth's exsector. Used for sawing long bones, the clamp held the bone while the saw was moved to and fro, ca. 1880. John A. Wyeth had been a Cavalry man under Nathan Bedford Forrest, before studying medicine. He later started the New York Polyclinic Medical School, a post-graduate institution.
Bullet extractor.
Aneurysm needle. Used for passing a ligature around a small artery, with as little disturbance as possible to surrounding tissue. Determining from the wooden handle, it is most likely Pre-Listerian.
Surgical needle holder.
Anesthetic apparatus.
Ether mask.
Collins needle for suturing silver wire.
Ecraseur Chassigmac's design. For removal of uterine tumors and polypi. Ca. 1890. Manufactured by George Tiemann & Co.
Hand lancet, possibly used as a veterinary instrument, early 19th century. Contained in a brass case, and "Jessop" is stamped on one of the fold-out blades.
Aneurysm needle, pre-Listerian times.
Davis and Kidder electric machine ca. 1850.
Civiale lithotrite. Ca. 1860.
did.provenance: Donated by Dr. Harry Shelley.

did.text: Obstetrical forceps. Ca. 1875.
Acupuncture set. Probably French and modern. Acupuncture instruments are still in use as they were 2,000 years ago. The principle of irritation -- counter irritation is the basis of acupuncture.

Moxibustion instrument. Ca 1960s. Punk or slow burning loose material is dropped through the handle to heat the metal bottom of the applicator to produce round burns and blisters on the skin. Oriental in origin.
did.provenance: Donated by Dr. Bernard M. Weinstein.

Saddlebags circa 1887 belonging to Dr. Nathaniel M. Lewis (1849-1933) who graduated from Vanderbilt in 1882 and practiced medicine in Nashville for 5 years after his graduation, and then practiced in Rutherford County. The saddlebags date from at least 1887, when he moved his practice to Rutherford Co. (per correspondence with great grandson Jay Maveety of Ashville, NC. maveety@charter.net 19 September 2013.

did.text: Halsted, William S. Arterial banding device, used to occlude the aorta gradually, above the aneurysm; invented by William S. Halsted, ca. 1900. Device is contained in black wooden case with glass front, which also contains a drawing which illustrates the band's use. The drawing was also done by Dr. Halsted. Donated by Dr. W. Andrew Dale, 1985. Dr. Dale received the device and drawing in 1974 from Dr. Herman E. Pearse. following the publication of Dr. Dale's article "Beginnings of Vascular Surgery," Surgery, vol. 76 (Dec. 1974), p. 849. The article discusses Dr. Halsted's development of the banding technique.
did.provenance: Donated by Dr. W. Andrew Dale, 1985.

Videocassette tapes. Medical School Centennial Celebration, 1975. Nine tapes labeled as follows: I. Vandy Morning, Dr. Wilson, Chancellor Heard, 1st part Dr. Bass. II. Vandy Morning, End Dr. Bass, Intro to Wiscoe(?) & Speech. III. Dr. Theodore Cooper, Medicine & Contemporary Society, Audience Shots. IV. Afternoon, 1st panel, Portraits on wall. V. 2nd panel ending in female speaker. VI. Vandy Afternoon, Ind. of 2nd panel Stahlman ending Vice Chancellor's Speech. VII. Vandy (evening) Cocktail party- Dinner shots, 1st introduction after meal. VIII. Vandy (evening) after dinner talk, with slides (rough) Dr. McSwain. IX. Vandy Night, final slides. There is also an Ultra High density-gamma oriented magnetic recording tape (2/25/75) copy of Centennial Celebration. Added to inventory March 25, 1994.

did.text: Audio tape, single reel magnetic recording tape of: "Symposium on the History of Pellagra, chaired by W. H. Sebrell, April 14, 1980, Anaheim, California. Added to inventory December 20, 1994.
did.provenance: Donated by William J. Darby, 1985.

did.text: Audio tapes, single reel magnetic recording tape of: "Human Nutrition Workshop and Nutrition Foundation Banquet," October 1-4, 1973. Includes presentations by Seals, Prathro, Lazar, Davis, Carter, Hunscher and Earl Butz. Added to inventory December 20, 1994.
did.provenance: Donated by William J. Darby, 1985.

did.text: Audio tape, single reel magnetic recording tape of: "New England Nutrition Symposium. Participants include: Dr. Gilbert Levine Mellon, Dr. Albert J. Robinson, Dr. Horace L. Sipple, Dr. James Allison, Dr. James H. Shaw, Dr. William H. Sebrell, Jr., Mr. Nevis Cook, October 30, 1963. Added to inventory December 20, 1994.
did.provenance: Donated by William J. Darby, 1985.

did.text: Audio tape, single reel magnetic recording tape of: "Nutritional Initiatives for the Federal Government." Introduction by K. W. McNutt, speakers; O. Greenberg, D. M. Hegsted. and A. P. Simopolus, April 14, 1980. Added to inventory December 20, 1994.
did.provenance: Donated by William J. Darby, 1985.

did.text: Audio tape, single reel magnetic recording tape of: Earl C. Butz Speech, Chicago Club, April 7, 1965. Added to inventory December 20, 1994.
did.provenance: Donated by William J. Darby, 1985.

did.text: Audio tape, single reel magnetic recording tape of: Excerpts from Carlton Fredricks interview program over Boston radio station WMEX, February, 1965. Added to inventory December 20, 1994.
did.provenance: Donated by William J. Darby, 1985.

did.text: Audio tape, single reel magnetic recording tape of: "Directors Meeting, November, 1970" (Union League Club?). Added to inventory December 20, 1994.
did.provenance: Donated by William J. Darby, 1985.

did.text: Audio tape, single reel magnetic recording tape of: "WJD (William J. Darby) speaking at November 5, 1971 Director's Meeting at the Union League Club." Added to inventory December 20, 1994.
did.provenance: Donated by William J. Darby, 1985.

did.text: Microfilm of American Journal of Clinical Nutrition, Volume 30-31 (1977-78), and Journal of Nutrition, Volume 102 (1972), 108-110 (1978-80). Added to inventory December 20, 1994.
did.provenance: Donated by William J. Darby, 1985.

did.text: Audio cassette recording of Pearson Tribute Dinner, January, 1974. Added to inventory December 20, 1994.

Audio tape, single reel magnetic recording tape of: "Centennial Celebration, February 25, 1975. Participants include: Dr. Alan Bass, Dr. Vernon Wilson, Chancellor Alexander Heard, Chester Burns, Dr. Clark Wescoe, Dr. Theodore Cooper, Dr. William W. Frye, Dr. Henry L. Douglas, Dr. Hollis E. Johnson, Dr. John C. Burch, Dr. Amos Christie, Dr. William F. Meacham, et al. Added to artifact inventory, December 20, 1994.

Motorized drill with foot pedal Manufactured by Hamilton Beach Mfg., ca. 1935. Used by Dr. Ernest Goodpasture and associates to drill holes in eggs (chic embryos) for the preparation of virus vaccines. Box in which drill is contained also contains miscellaneous attachments that go with the drill. Added to inventory December 20, 1994.
Microscope slides belonging to Dr. Ernest Goodpasture concerning his studies from ca. 1950-1960. Note that only the box is labeled with the artifact number. Added to inventory December 20, 1994.

Cornerstone box from the cornerstone of the old hospital. The cornerstone and box were opened in 1969 after construction on the Twenty-first avenue side of the building covered over the original entrance. The box is made of copper. Added to inventory January, 1995.
Seal of the Vanderbilt University Medical Department Witherspoon Club. Black metal with handle and two screw holes to mount to a table or desk. Listed and described in inventory January 12, 1995.

Medicine Case. Dark brown leather, ca. 1900, containing 11 medicine bottles with metal screw tops containing pills. Manufactured by the Upjohn Company. Also contains a card describing the assortment of pills (that were originally) contained in the case. Added to inventory January, 1995.
Medicine Case. Dark brown leather ca. 1880 containing an assortment of nineteen various medicine bottles. Added to inventory January, 1995.
Pelvimeter, ca. 1930, steel, chrome-plated, centimeter graduated scale etched on side. Manufactured by the Betz Company. Added to inventory January, 1995.
Vaginal retractor, solid metal, ca. 20th century. Added to inventory January, 1995.
Vaginal retractor, solid metal, ca. 20th century. Added to inventory January, 1995.
Vaginal retractor, solid metal with wooden handle, ca. 1875. Added to inventory January, 1995.
Nasal specula (three), ca. 1920, metal, two manufactured by Dittmar and one by Penn. Added to inventory January, 1995.
Stethoscope, wooden, replica of the Laennec style of stethoscope. Added to inventory January, 1995.
Retractor, ca 1900, manufactured by M. Wocher. Added to inventory January, 1995.
Gynecologic depressor, wooden handle, ca. 1890. Added to inventory January, 1995.
Forceps, ca. 1900, perhaps lithotomy forceps, manufactured by Charriere, Paris. Added to inventory January, 1995.
Throat mirror, stainless steel, 20th century. Added to inventory January, 1995.
Tuning fork, ca. 1950, manufactured by Roerig. Added to inventory January, 1995.
Ophthalmoscope with battery-powered light, ca. 1920., manufactured by the Wellsworth-Dezeng Company. Contained in a black case. Added to inventory January, 1995.
Glass beaker, hand blown, ca. 1850, used by John Berrien Lindsley. Added to inventory January 12, 1995.
did.provenance: Donated by Margaret Lindsley Warden.

did.text: Doctor's bag, brown leather, ca. 1890. Added to inventory January, 1995.
Doctor's bag, black leather, ca 1890. Contains an assortment of obstetrical instruments. Added to inventory January, 1995.
Scarificator, brass, twelve bladed ca. 1850. Has an eagle and shield symbol on the bottom. Added to inventory January, 1995.
Scarificator, brass, nine bladed ca. 1850. Added to inventory January, 1995.
Spring lancet, ca. 1840 manufactured by Zeitz, New York. Contained in a brown case with a gold eagle and shield symbol on the top. Added to inventory January, 1995.
Cupping set cups with miscellaneous accessories ca. 1890, manufactured by Huston Brothers, Chicago. Contained in a black box. Added to inventory January, 1995.
Amputating knife, long, ca. 1875, manufactured by Tiemann and Co. Added to inventory January, 1995.

Paper weight, bronze. Commissioned at the retirement of Dr. Simon Flexner from the Rockefeller Institute. Profile of Simon Flexner on the obverse and the front gate of the Rockefeller Institute on the reverse. Added to inventory January, 1995.
Urethral syringe, hard rubber, ca. 1890, found in Nashville. Added to inventory January, 1995.

Post-nasal balloon catheter for the control of bleeding in the nasopharynx, ca. 1950. Designed by Dr. Cyril Fox and manufactured by the Bittner Corporation. Contained in original cardboard box with a sheet of description and directions. Added to inventory January, 1995.
Hypodermic "special" needle, manufactured by Becton Dickinson and Company. Contained in a purple top cardboard box. Added to inventory January, 1995.
Hemometer, ca. 1890, manufactured by E. Leitz, Berlin, Germany. Contained in black case, incomplete and in poor condition. Added to inventory January, 1995.

Surgical case, black leather ca. 1890 containing miscellaneous surgical instruments including clamps amputation saw, sutures, hypodermic needles, and tourniquet. The case was manufactured for the Theo Tafel Company, Nashville, but the instruments appear not to be original to the case Added to inventory January, 1995.
Amputation saw, ca. 1890, rusty. Added to inventory January, 1995.

Ashtray, brass, made from a spent, large gun shell ca. 1944. Slotted to hold cigarettes and a stand to hold matches. Made for Dr. Rosenfeld by a grateful patient, well used. Added to inventory January, 1995.
did.provenance: Donated by Dr. Louis Rosenfeld.

did.text: Brooks, Barney. Letter from Dr. William S. Halsted in Baltimore, Md. to Dr. Barney Brooks. Dated February 11, 1914. Added to inventory February, 1995.
Thermometer, vest pocket, worn by R. H. Kampmeier while in practice in Castle Gate Utah. Glass, contained in a twist fashioned aluminum carrying case. Added to inventory February, 1995.
did.provenance: Donated by Dr. Rudolph H. Kampmeier.

did.text: Patent Medicine. "Raspberry Leaves Rubus Strigosus, S. W. Gould & Bros. Botanic Garden Malden Mass." Contained in a sealed and unopened paper-wrapped box, ca. 1910. Added to inventory February, 1995.
did.provenance: Donated by Dr. Rudolph H. Kampmeier, [September 1985?].

did.text: Chloroform bottle, corked, amber, empty, manufactured for E. R. Squibb and Sons, ca. 1905. Added to inventory February, 1995.
did.provenance: Donated by Dr. Rudolph H. Kampmeier, [September 1985?]

did.text: Medicine. Permian crystals, manufactured by Tarrant and Co. New York, contained in corked bottle, ca 1870. Added to inventory February, 1995.
"Corn Plasters." manufactured by Bauer & Black, Chicago. Contained in a small black cardboard box, ca. 1898. Added to inventory February, 1995.

Vaccine. "Glycerinized Vaccine Lymph on Ivory Points," manufactured by the National Vaccine Est., Washington. Contained in a light blue cardboard box, ivory point contained in a paraffine pocket, ca. 1898. Added to inventory February, 1995.
Patent medicine. "Antikamnia & Quinine Laxative Tablets" manufactured by the Antikamnia Chemical Co., St. Louis." Contained in a sample tin tablet box, ca. 1890. Added to inventory February, 1995.
Hypodermic tablet samples manufactured by Parke, Davis & Co., Detroit, Michigan. Atropine sulphate tablets contained in a sample tin box, ca. 1890. Added to inventory February, 1995.
Patent medicine. "Sharp and Dohme Emulsion Petroleum Compound," large empty bottle ca 1910. Added to inventory February, 1995.

Figurine, "Portrait of an Asthmatic Attack, Nayarit, Mexico, 400-800 A.D. " Primitive reproduction, carved from volcanic stone, (once upon a time) mounted on a wooden block, contained in a plastic bag. Added to inventory February, 1995.
Wheat seed. Pyrex tube containing " First prize dark hard winter wheat Sterling Co., Variety -- Wichita, test weight 64.8, L. F. Givens." Added to inventory February, 1995.
Ophthalmoscope, battery-powered, ca. 1915, manufactured by the Welch Allyn, Co., Auburn, New York. Contained with attachments in a black case. Added to inventory February, 1995.
Pocket case containing scalpels, clamps, depressors, forceps, etc. Case manufactured for the Theo Tafel Company, tri-fold black leather, ca. 1890, poor condition. Added to inventory February, 1995.
Catheter, metal urethral, ca. 1890. Added to inventory February, 1995.
Sound, conical, curved, used in the treatment of strictures. The numbers 25 and 14 are stamped on the handle, manufactured by Enqua -- Paris, ca 1890. Added to inventory February, 1995.
Blood pressure apparatus patented and manufactured by G. P. Piling & Son Co., Philadelphia, ca. 1910. Contained in a black leather case, apparently incomplete. Added to inventory February, 1995.
Battery box, portable, manufactured by V. Mueller & Company, ca. 1910, walnut with handle on top lid. Added to inventory February, 1995.

Ophthalmic instruments, including ivory-handled scalpels, knives, retractors, forceps, hooks, etc. Contained in a black leather case manufactured for the Merowitz Bros., New York, ca. 1910. Most, but not all the instruments are manufactured by Merowitz. Belonged to a G. W. Hale, whose name is lettered on the top. Added to inventory February, 1995.

Nutritional food charts. Bar graphs on poster board showing values of particular foods in relation to various bodily functions. Also, there are a few thermofax transparencies. Note: that only the box is numbered and not the individual items. Added to inventory March, 1995.
did.provenance: Donated by Bertlyn Bosley, 1990.

did.text: Plaques, certificates, and diplomas awarded to Bertlyn Bosley, Ph.D.; a silver plate inscribed "The Bertlyn Bosley Award of Excellence.. in North Carolina, 1981; and several Spanish language posters for nutritional awareness campaigns; box of starched collars and a black and white uniform cap (for dietitians?) Note: that only the box is numbered and not the individual items. Added to inventory in 1995.
did.provenance: Donated by Bertlyn Bosley.

did.text: Carrying case, brown leather with alligator stamped pattern, purple felt interior containing medical instruments manufactured by Cameron's Surgical Specialty Co., ca. 1925. Observation instruments which are battery powered include: ophthalmoscope, speculum, endoscope, and a "Vitrohm Adjuster." Also, there are other attachments including bulbs and fuses. See also: boxes 45-48.
did.provenance: Donated by Martin A. Meacham.

did.text: Miscellaneous dental instruments, ca. 1890-1920, belonging to Dr. John Benjamin Hopkins and Edna Love Hopkins. Instruments include: forceps, root extractors, and lancets. Note: that only the box is numbered and not the instruments contained within. Added to inventory March, 1995.
did.provenance: Donated by Mrs. Ben Hopkins, July, 1989.

did.text: Miscellaneous ophthalmologic and otolaryngological instruments and charts, ca. 1950- 1960, which belonged to William W. Wilkerson, M.D. Instruments include: head mirror, otoscope-ophthalmoscope, and retinoscope. Also, diagnostic plastic test objects, a three-dimensional vectographic exercise booklet, and an eye chart contained in a booklet. Note: that only the box is labeled. Added to inventory March 8, 1995.

Miscellaneous obstetrical and surgical instruments, ca. 20th century, including clamps, depressors, speculums, probes, retractors, forceps, hooks, curettes, douche, etc. Note: that only the box is labeled. Added to inventory March 8, 1994.

Vaccines. Three wooden tubes containing glycerinized vaccine lymph. Two are manufactured by H. K Mulford Co. and one by Parke Davis & Co. All three were manufactured for use by January, 1903. Contained in a short mailing tube. Added to inventory March, 1995.
Microscopic lenses (fourteen) of varying powers, ca. 1900 contained in a green leather covered case. Added to inventory March 8, 1995.

Scales, portable, golden colored, tripod with singular dish, (plastic -- not original) balanced above a curved, graduated scale which is attached to a counterweight. Ca. 1920, manufactured by Depose(?), Germany. Added to inventory March 9, 1995.

Magnifier used by travelling bible salesmen in the late nineteenth century. Squared metal rod with a graduated scale etched on the side, a stationary magnifying lens with a handle on one end, and a round metal plate with a handle which slides on the rod. The plate is inscribed with "count the dots" on the side of facing the lens. Appears to be ophthalmologic in nature. Added to inventory March 9, 1995.

Hydrometer, ca. 1920, double bulbed. The first is flat, and pill-shaped containing mercury. The second bulb is a larger and capsule-shaped. The flat section of the tube above the two bulbs has a graduated scale on a white insert. "Diabetes" and "Made in Germany" is printed on the opposite side of the insert. Contained in a black cardboard tube. Added to inventory March 9, 1995.
Trepanning elevator and rasps. Solid metal double-sided tool manufactured by J Reinders & Co., New York, ca 1880. Added to inventory March 10, 1995.
Two trepanning instruments ca. 18th and early 19th century. Lenticular knife, and a raspatory. Wooden handles and apparently part of a set. Added to inventory March 10, 1995
Pocket case for ampoules, ca. 1920. nickel silver, manufactured for Admiral B-D, Rutherford, New Jersey. Added to inventory March 10, 1995.
Aspirator, ca. 1900, includes rubber hoses and stoppers, and needles. Contained in a white cotton canvass roll-up case. Added to inventory March 10, 1995.
Cysto-lithic staff, channeled, stainless steel, ca 1900. Handle missing. Added to inventory March 10, 1995.
Mendeléff Dimitri Ivanovitsch. Framed portrait with biographical description of Dimitri Ivanovitsch Mendléff (1834-1907).
did.provenance: Donated by Dr. E. Neige Todhunter (from the Department of Biochemistry), May 7, 1979. Added to inventory May 26, 1995. Transferred from Vanderbilt Department of Biochemistry.

did.text: Booklet of WWII era German patient casulty tags used by doctors in the field to describe the extent of patient’s injuries, history etc.
did.provenance: Donated by Dr. Henry M. Carney, September 6, 1995.
